text: [Music]
[Applause]
[Music]
hello I'm caric a technical account
manager here at the AWS office in Los
Angeles today I'm going to show you how
to add HTTP security headers to Amazon
cloudfront responses let's get
started before we dive in let's talk
about what HTTP security headers are
these are special directives sent by a
web server to a browser to improve the
security posture of your application
HTTP security headers can help mitigate
various vulnerabilities such as
clickjacking referral leakage and crossy
scripting attacks cloudfront is a
Content delivery network service from
AWS that catches and delivers your web
content to users with high performance
by adding security headers at the
cloudfront level you can enforce these
policies on all requests before they
reach your origin server this adds an
extra layer of protection for your
application now let's get into the task
and see how to add these headers using
the
console after logging into the AWS
Management console navigate to the
cloudfront console on the left panel
choose policies select the response
headers tab choose create response
headers policy under detailed section
enter the name of the rule and provide a
description note based on your use case
you can turn on security headers
required for your application under the
security headers optional section turn
on strict Transport Security header X
content type options refer policy for
refer policy select no
refer choose create to save the changes
on the left side of the screen choose
the hamburger menu and select
distributions now select the
distribution that you want to add the
policy choose the behaviors tab here you
can configure how cloudfront catches
content based on different paths in your
website choose the path where you want
to add the security headers in our
example we'll select the default path
pattern and then choose edit Behavior go
to the respond headers policy section
under the drop- down list and then
select the security header rule that was
created earlier choose save changes to
apply your
configuration to test the changes open
the terminal window and enter in the
following command and you will see the
results you have successfully added HTTP
security headers to your cloudfront
distribution which makes your web
application more secure remember
security is an ongoing process so keep
yourself updated on the latest threats
and best practices and now you know how
to add HTTP security headers to Cloud
friend responses thank thanks for
watching and happy cloud computing from
all of us here at AWS
[Applause]
[Music]
